qas.question: What year was Jeannette Rankin vote against war the first time?
When did she vote a second time against war?
What were conscientious objectors sent to Montana to do?

answers.text: smokejumpers and for other forest fire-fighting duties.

context: In 1940, Jeannette Rankin had once again been elected to Congress, and in <a1_0>1941<a1_0/>, as she did in <a0_0>1917<a0_0/>, she voted against the United States' declaration of war. This time she was the only vote against the war, and in the wake of public outcry over her vote, she required police protection for a time. Other pacifists tended to be those from "peace churches" who generally opposed war. Many individuals from throughout the U.S. who claimed conscientious objector status were sent to Montana during the war as <a2_0>smokejumpers and for other forest fire-fighting duties.
